For her remarkable sacrifice in service to our nation, 2LT Slanger was posthumously awarded the Purple Heard and in 1945 an Army hospital ship was named in her memory. 

Today, we honor and remember Second Lieutenant Frances Slanger. #JewishAmericanHeritageMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E18bjiQWUAIxIa-.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E18bmKuXoAEUL5a.jpg
Her service came to a tragic and abrupt end upon her death in October 1944 when the 45th Field Hospital, where she was stationed, came under attack by Germans.

Her petition was approved and she arrived in Normandy just four days after D-Day to answer the call of duty. 2LT Slanger was soon recognized for her remarkable compassion for the injured soldiers in her care.
During WWII, after seeing the horrors of the war, she enlisted in the U.S. Army Nurse Corps and petitioned to be allowed to serve overseas during the war effort.

An immigrant from Poland, Slanger came to the United States when she was just 7 years old following the first World War. Seeking to help others, she attended Boston Nursing School to fulfill her dream of becoming a nurse. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E18bcdpXsAAhYm-.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E18bdS2WQAIPUgi.jpg

Today in the #WomensVetsTaskForce series highlighting the achievements of Jewish American #womenvets, we recognize Second Lieutenant Frances Y. Slanger, a nurse for the U.S. Army during World War II. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E18bFAlXoAk8nEs.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E18bQ7tWQAMWd-S.jpg

The climate crisis is here, and it is urgent that we act. The #ClimateActionPlan is a blueprint for climate action this Congress, and we are already implementing it.

During my time in Congress, I have witnessed the effects of the #ClimateCrisis. Farmers are struggling to make ends meet as extreme weather jeopardizes their harvest. Fishermen report southern species off our coast. The snowboard shop in Beaverton is selling more skateboards.

My two wonderful children are another reason I am passionate about #ORClimateAction. Parenting reaffirmed my commitment to wanting to preserve the planet ‚Äì not just for my children, but for future generations and for humankind.

As a student, I worked at Legal Aid helping low-income clients who were struggling. Many families are just one car accident away from economic disaster. The same is true of frontline communities in the climate crisis. #ClimateSolutions can help by creating more good-paying jobs.

My beloved mom recently passed away, but she continues to be my guiding light. Mom was always ahead of her time. She was an avid recycler and promoter of recycling, grew a beautiful organic garden, played the piano, and painted modern art.

Thank you @OEConline for the chance to discuss my work on @ClimateCrisis. In times like these we can draw strength from the reasons we began this work. My Mom, Oregon‚Äôs natural beauty, my wonderful kids, my time at Legal Aid: these are the roots of my commitment to #ClimateAction
